page.title: 06WOODGREEN VILLAGE HALL
page.content: IN WOODGREEN VILLAGE HALL, WHICH STANDS NEXT TO ST.BONIFACE CHURCH, THERE ARE INTERESTING LIFE_SIZE MURALS ON THE WALLS. THEY WERE PAINTED IN WATER COLOURS AT THE BEGINNING OF THE 1930'S AND THE CARNEGIE TRUST PROVIDED MOST OF THE MONEY. THE SCENES DEPICT VILLAGE LIFE AT THAT TIME AND ALL THE CHARACTERS IN THEM WERE WOODGREEN INHABITANTS. THE PICTURES INCLUDE SUCH EVENTS AS THE METHODIST SUNDAY SCHOOL OUTING, THE LOCAL FLOWER SHOW, THE WOODGREEN FOLK-DANCING GROUP AND CIDER-MAKING. THEY ATTRACT MANY VISTORS AND THEY HAVE ALSO BEEN THE SUBJECT OF A TELEVISION PROGRAMME. SALISBURY INFIRMARY APPEARS IN ONE MURAL , FOR MANY VILLAGERS PAID ONE PENNY A WEEK FOR HOSPITAL TREATMENT IN CASE THEY SHOULD THEY NEED IT .
